DeregistrationReasonOtherText: The Trident Seafoods Pier-91 Facility has been sold to another company.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EPA Risk Management Plan

Executive Summary:

12/8/06

Trident Seafood?s Pier-91 facility is located on the Port of Seattle?s Pier 89 -91 properties, located in the Inter Bay region of Seattle proper. The pier property covers greater than 152 acres and Trident?s facility is located almost exactly in the middle; covering nearly 168,000 square feet. Fortunately, with respect to exposure, this central property location gives the facility, which freezes seafood products using ammonia, a fairly large spatial (area) buffer to the North, East and West. Directly to the south is another Cold Storage that also uses ammonia as a refrigerant. These central property locations help mitigate potential exposure to residential areas adjacent to the pier properties.

Trident Seafoods Corporate and Management Staff are committed to the Health and Safety of our employees, surrounding communities and the environment. Our facility managers are equally committed to these same safety and health values. 

We have designed and implemented a complete and comprehensive facility Safety Plan with supporting Policies. 

Because our facility now has on the premises anhydrous ammonia in excess of 10,000 pounds we have completed and administered the PSM Program working closely with the Washington Industrial and Health Administration (WISHA) Consultation and Training.  Herein we submit to the EPA this application for RMP Plan approval.

The facility utilizes this refrigeration system to freeze and store seafood as well as various other food products. The total quantity of ammonia contained in the system mandates compliance with the OSHA\WISHA Process Safety Management Program and the EPA Level 3 Risk Management Program. These programs are designed to assure the health and safety of all onsite employees, as well as offsite public and environmental receptors. 

The Pier-91 facility utilizes a common refrigeration system to produce refrigeration for several distinct and separate processes, sometimes at

different ultimate temperatures. This facility has essentially two business units; one half of the plant is a large Cold Storage and Distribution facility, the other half is a Food Processing facility. The common refrigeration system has capabilities to provide three different temperature ranges within the plant. The smallest portion of the of the refrigeration load is to maintain + 40?F to +50?F refrigeration for plant processing water, air conditioning and loading dock temperature control. The second largest refrigeration load operates at -20?F for a large Cold Stores and a smaller holding freezer. The last and largest portion of the refrigeration load is to produce and maintain -45?F (processing ?blast? freezers).

The facility?s refrigeration system was engineered and designed to meet or exceed current industry Standards and regulations. 

The refrigeration system uses industry Standard materials, components, and follows the IIAR and refrigeration industry guidelines which actually provide overlapping layers of safety and protection of the refrigeration system and its components. These overlapping layers of protection are provided through the use of automatic and manual controls which minimize operating deviation and maintain the system within safe operational parameters. In the most critical operations, there are also redundant back-up systems to these overlapping control systems.

Along with the inherent sound engineering and design that was originally built into the system, Trident Seafoods has taken a very pro-active approach to all aspects of safety, especially our approach to chemical safety as it pertains to ammonia. We have provided extensive training for all employees working onsite as to the hazards involved with ammonia and other onsite chemical substances.  We have conducted several mock evacuation drills to expose and train all employees of their roles and responsibilities should an emergency arise. 

As for the use of other chemicals involved in th

e cleaning and sanitation processes, we have conducted extensive training on the use of PPE and safe handing for these substances as well. 

Through the long process of developing these safety programs and procedures, we have made every possible effort to comply with all applicable OSHA, WISHA, and EPA regulation. All aspects of our general plant safety programs, procedures and policies comply with the latest WISHA Standards as determined by recent inspections. 

The PSM Program was written following OSHA guidelines and implemented interactively with WISHA Consultation and Training. The refrigeration system design complies fully with the ASHRE and ANSI Standards.

The ammonia piping system is completely labeled and marked in accordance with OSHA recommendations and follows IIAR Best Practices. It is our policy at this facility to conduct and document monthly safety meetings. As well, there are specific and designated employee operators required each year to attend refresher training relating to safe ammonia systems operation.

There have been no onsite or off-site ammonia related incidents resulting in any injury, death, property or environmental damage during the 5-year accident history period required to complete this Risk Management Plan submittal. 

We have put considerable effort into designing a comprehensive Emergency Response Program. The PSM Plan has been fully implemented at the facility with direct input and appropriate training to include all facility department staff. 
We have also worked closely with local emergency responders on how to mitigate and further reduce potential exposures to our employees and surrounding community and environment.

We have always strived to make improvements in our process and operational systems. This philosophy also applies towards our view and commitment to safety. 

During the writing and administration phase of the PSM Program, we conducted a complete and comprehensive Process Hazard Analysis on the refrigeration syste

m as a whole. From that analysis we identified and documented all findings that related to safety and/or system integrity. 

We have addressed all critical issues to the satisfaction of WIHSA and are now addressing remaining non-critical issues. Although some of the corrective actions were very costly to Trident, it remains our practice to correct any and all safety related issues in an expedient and effective manner. 

Currently we are in the planning and design phase of a project to complete the piping connections between the remainder of the refrigeration system and the emergency water diffusion system initiated in 2005. Completion of this project will help further mitigate exposure to surrounding properties.

We will continue to make every effort to fully comply with the Risk Management Plan, the PSM Program, and to do our utmost best to operate this facility safely and responsibly.

Please contact me at (206) 272-3921 if you have any questions.



Michael J. Hawes
Facility\Safety & Health Manager

Trident Seafoods, Pier-91
